title: Munich Ranks as Most Overvalued Global Market, at Risk of Bubble
text:
The risk of a housing bubble is highest across the Eurozone and Canada, while lessening across U.S. cities, according to a report Monday from UBS.



The annual UBS Global Real Estate Bubble Index analyzed the housing markets of 24 global financial centers and found seven cities where home prices are unsustainably high.

Munich ranked as the most overvalued housing market due to its strong local economy, population growth and a lack of new housing supply.



The German city was followed by Toronto, Hong Kong and Amsterdam. Frankfurt, Vancouver and Paris are in bubble risk territory, too, with low interest rates considered the main driver in European cities in particular, the investment bank said.



UBS

“On a global level, economic uncertainty is outweighing the effect of falling interest rates on urban housing demand,” Mark Haefele, chief investment officer at UBS Global Wealth Management, said in the report. “However, in parts of the Eurozone, low rates have still helped to push real estate valuations into bubble risk territory.”



The term “bubble” refers to a “substantial and sustained mispricing of an asset, the existence of which cannot be proved unless it bursts,” according to UBS.



But none of the five U.S. cities analyzed in the index are considered to be at risk.

Though strong employment and income growth have helped push up prices in California, strained affordability and falling international demand have capped price growth in San Francisco and Los Angeles, the report said.



The Boston housing market has benefited from its good affordability and economic appeal for businesses and high-income earners.



In New York, affordability issues and an unfavorable tax treatment have led to declining home values, according to UBS.



And in Chicago, the only city in the report to be considered undervalued, weak economic development has led to price increases of less than 20% since 2000.
